body:
Innermost, hmm. I would have thought outermost as Steve did. 

Can you record the motivation here if there is one from slack so we have the history.

So first - I can definitely see both views here. Not saying I'm definitely right. :) Here is my motivation.

I've got an a sequence that looks like this:

X is - figure out a search term ("foo") and return it
Y is an external Twitter page that takes a term and returns an array or results
Z stores the results, BUT, I want to remember that I searched for "foo" so I can record that with each result.

A Forwarder should handle this, but is a bit complex to use (I say this even though I've written a blog post on it :). What I'd love is some ability to say, "For this sequence, store the value 1 in some global variable X." To do this, I was going to maybe use Redis, but I'd need a unique ID to store the value since I could have multiple activations at once. A unique sequence ID would do it.

p.s. Even better would be a new, second argument to OpenWhisk actions for context. Something we could read/write to in our more complex sequences.
closing in favor of #2688

This workaround seems to work: https://stackoverflow.com/a/34386471
Example:
`MSYS_NO_PATHCONV=1  wsk action invoke /whisk.system/utils/echo -p message hello --blocking --result`

@sven-lange-last @tysonnorris seems like the early wrappings are solved by the longer line length.

I now opted for 120 chars as that seems to fit github's diff view.

This is a bit more nuanced - when status code, headers, and body are all missing, the sensible default is clear. But what if only some of those values are specified?

As in a status code is specified, no body and no headers? This can lead to content negotiation errors.

Or a body is specified and no headers? Should we infer JSON type for example? This is something we considered useful to avoid base64 encoding an http response. We currently infer JSON content type, and I think this is sensible. For a string which must otherwise be base64 encoded, the content-type must be set in the headers.

Join credit to @akrabat and @csantanapr as this issue is the result of discussion among the three of us on slack.
@csantanapr I have fixed this patch.

Taking stock of combinations, and in addition to the comments above, here's a summary of the various handlers:

When body is present and is of type `String` or `JSON` (below header is loosely used to mean `content-type` header value):
```
body: String, no header    -> text/html
body: String, with header  -> interpret according to header
body: JSON, no header      -> application/json
body: JSON, with header that is not JSON compatible  -> ignore header
```

Now when the action response is:
1. `{}`, respond with status code = 204
1. `{body:, [headers:] }` respond with status code = 200 and body according to rules above
1. `{statusCode}` -> respond with code (have to suppress possible 406)
1. `{statusCode, headers}` -> respond with status code (have to suppress possible 406)
1. `{statusCode, body}` -> respond with status code and body according to rules above (content negotiation may fail)
1. `{statusCode, body, headers}` -> respond with status code and body (content negotiation may fail)

It may be further desirable to treat a value of `""` and `null` for `body` the same as a missing body - that is no content type.

Join credit to @akrabat and @csantanapr as this issue is the result of discussion among the three of us on slack.
Swagger supports special characters, so closing this issue for now.

The invoker does already have a shutdown hook which is supposed to clean up. That hook needs to wait until all the user load is finished and then return so the container can be removed. It also needs to make sure no load is accepted anymore (potentially by stop sending pings to the controller).

If we're able to do that, we can remove the ansible jobs which clean up and gain the functionality that you're after.

What's the desired goal here? Note that the current loadbalancer is strictly based numbering the instances from 0-(numberOfInstances-1). I don't like that, but that's how it is today.

The patch here addressed a bug: the invoker tids would be an infinite sequence of 0s. The invoker however does not generate tids (no rest interface). Separately, the naming/indexing of invokers can be addressed.

to expand on what Rodric said:  
 invoker0 would generate tids 0,0,0,...
 invoker1 would generate 1,2,3,...
 invoker2 would generate 2,4,6,...
This fixes all of the invokers to generate tids 1,2,3,...   (if they were actually to generate tids)

A side note that perhaps once the instances have unique, not ordinal, ids, the `tid` could be extended from `tid_NNN` to `tid_id_NNN` and avoid the delta increments entirely.
That's correct. Once the throttle is settled none of the tests generate enough traffic to kick it back on.

    Running replicator: http://whisk_admin:some_passw0rd@172.17.0.1:5984, http://whisk_admin:some_passw0rd@172.17.0.1:5984, replicatortest_whisk_local_, 10 minutes, false, List()

Keeping the same ID across restarts is a good point.  I was thinking we will need to have some mechanism for draining the topics of offline invokers, so we could just use that more frequently and not worry about reusing invoker ids across restarts. But that might not be optimal. 

Perhaps the path to pursue is allowing invoker IDs to be an arbitrary alphanumeric string (anything that is legal to embed in a kafka topic name) that the invoker computes _somehow_ without needing to communicate with the controller (by reading a command line, by computing a function on its ip address, by otherwise picking something out of its environment/filesystem, randomUUID, ...).  The controller/load balancer just uses the ID (provided to it implicitly by ping messages on the health topic) to create the kafka topic invoker-ID and the loadbalancer internally maps the ID to a dense numbering of currently active invokers to support hashing incoming work to invokers.

The invoker id could a uuid. When it registers with the load balancer, in the spirit of this pr, it is assigned a message topic to start draining. This topic id is thus orthogonal to the invoker id. This would make the protocol for restart of an invoker a bit more chatty (to recover a lost topic processor) but could be better longer term, and maybe gets us closer to work stealing.

Hello,
(My Id is Kavitha Devara on Slack Channels) 
Im in favor of making the Invoker Stateless( from Kubernetes perspective) - Am happy to see some momentum on this.
 Im experimenting with  the following way of obraining the InstanceId from the Controller:
"curl controller.openwhisk:8080/invokers"  ---> (This should give the current list of Invokers)

and calling this  API in the "Invoker", to get the next available Id,  before it can bootstrap itself up with an ID. 
Use the existing API to get the length of current Invokers and Instantiate the next Invoker with the next index (OR) write a new REST API  in Controller.scala, to get "availableIndex" for the Invoker. 

"avialable Indexes" can be a pool of Indexes/UUIDs maninatined by the Controller that may be assigned for new Invoker Instance creation. 

Any thoughts on this kind of solution?

@tysonnorris @sven-lange-last any last opinions from you?

I prematurely added documentation here: https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/wiki/Contributing:-Git-guidelines#scala

I have this problem when 
**Executing**:
/openwhisk# ./gradlew distDocker

**Problem**:
/root/.sdkman/candidates/java/current/bin/java: 1: /root/.sdkman/candidates/java/current/bin/java: Syntax error: end of file unexpected (expecting ")")

Wrapping seems better, at least in the example I ran into before. 
I would favor adding to the config:
- expand imports: ```rewrite.rules = [SortImports,ExpandImportSelectors]```

Are we going to introduce splunk into the system or treat it as an external store that can be injected into a deployment? I'm confused by the description and the changes - thanks in advance for clarification. 

I would have expected an abstract interface for draining activation logs and a concrete implementation using the existing couchdb store. 

A word of caution: using docker logs to fetch logs is historically a recipe for docker daemon locks up and kernel panics. It doesn't work under load.

I really like the idea of cleaning up our views.
The only problem I see, is with already running production environments. Depending on the size of the database it could take a long time to compute the new view. In this time, the views would return nothing and customers could see errors on `action list`, ...
What do you think about a versioning our design documents?
The advantage would be, that everyone could create the v2-document in the production database, and after it is computed, you can configure OpenWhisk to use v2 of the Design doc.
After some period we could deprecate v1 of the design doc and remove it from the repository and database.
I think this would also help a lot for future Design doc changes.
An example will be very helpful. Thanks
@tysonnorris SortImports and ExpandImportSelectors are incompatible (I tried it). I'm also in favor of keeping the grouping as is, although I'd prefer the formatter to auto-group, which it doesn't.

Hi, is there any progress on the issue? Thanks.

The rest of the fields are dropped deliberately:
https://github.com/apache/incubator-openwhisk/blob/master/common/scala/src/main/scala/whisk/core/entity/ActivationResult.scala#L170

The programming model declares as a standard that, semantically, an action invocation failed if and only if the response object seen by the end user contains an error field.

That said, we can discuss relaxing this.
Yes I don't see the benefits of the filtering.

Is the OS info part of the header?
This needs a rebase to reflect the latest changes to SPILoader.
That is the path the `docker` binary is expected to be in the Invoker container. The Invoker shells out to that binary for some operations.

@rabbah, @drcariel, @mdeuser, looks like we can easily append the OS to the user-agent if we want to. To do so, import `runtime`, and call `runtime.GOOS`, which will return `windows`, `linux`, or `darwin`.
The runtime package also provides the ability to retrieve the CPU architecture through `runtime.GOARCH`.
i'd prefer to do that OS addition in a separate PR.

I've been confused by the need to use the whisk.common.Logging class at all - is there any reason not to use slf4j classes directly, like many projects do? e.g. instead of every class having to pass Logging around, use something like ```val logger: Logger = LoggerFactory.getLogger(this.getClass)``` (or one per package, instead of one per class, etc). This way you can a) get rid of Logging code in the codebase and b) enable logger customization for specific packages/classes using standard conventions (via logback config)

Similarly, it may be possible to use MDC for TransactionId (instead of passing it everywhere), and slf4j markers (or some custom layout?) instead of (or in conjunction with) existing LoggingMarkers.

It's unclear whether these specialized logging utilities were added for specific reasons, but if not, it may be nice to use readily available tools for these jobs.
rebased to resolve conflicts with Scala reformat.   @cbickel any review comments?
@bbrowning Thanks for your reply. So If I want to use my own docker, am I editing 'core/invoker/Dockerfile' and rebuild and deploy?

@tysonnorris I looked into using plain slf4j loggers but using MDC seems to be a kinda non-starter because we don't specifically take control on a per Thread basis and slf4j's documentation says, that MDC should not be reset a bazillion times. I don't have much experience here though, if you have an idea on how to solve that I'd be very glad because as you said, going standard would be very nice!

In general, I'm in favor of this approach. It looks sensible to me. I cannot overlook all the sideeffects of how the CLI is built and distributed at this point though.
